text: [Music]
whether you are an associate manager or
a senior executive what you say how you
say it when you say it to whom you say
it and whether you say it within the
proper context are critical components
of your strategic leadership potential
this executive voice is less about your
performance and more about your
strategic instincts understanding of
context and awareness of the signals you
send in your daily interactions and
communications
developing an executive voice can mean
the difference between success and
failure in your communication and
leadership style here are some tips to
help you add a more strategic executive
voice to your leadership toolkit
first understand the context of the call
meeting or discussion that you're in by
finding out in advance what your
expected role is this can help you avoid
the dreaded deer in the headlights
feeling that comes with throwing out an
uninformed idea or saying something that
doesn't fit the agenda
for example if you are the primary
authority on a topic then it's likely
that the context would require you to
lead the meeting and make any final
decisions but if you are one of several
executives who might have input then
sharing your view and connecting the
dots with others rather than stealing
the spotlight with your great ideas
would be your role
and if you are in learning mode and are
not asked to present at a meeting then
your role when it comes to communication
would be to observe and listen
second be a visionary by taking an
enterprise view that focuses less on
your personal role and more on the wider
organization
articulate reasons for change and help
guide decisions around individual and
corporate actions and connect the dots
for others show how your decisions
affect those around the table your staff
and the company as a whole
next cultivate strategic relationships
by reaching out to at least one person
each week who is outside of your
immediate team or functional area
learn how they fit into the business as
a whole their goals and challenges and
ways you might support them as a
strategic business partner
interacting with senior leaders and
executives will give you perspective on
the organization's goals changes and top
priorities and help you avoid getting
caught up in the day-to-day minutiae
and bring solutions not just problems to
the table
leading strategically with a strong
executive voice involves focusing on
solving rather than just finger-pointing
at difficult issues
analyze situations brainstorm ideas that
go beyond the obvious and even if you
don't have the perfect answer
demonstrate your ability to come up with
clever solutions
and finally stay calm in the pressure
cooker when everyone around you is
losing their composure
stick with facts no matter how stressed
you feel and you'll provide level-headed
leadership with a more powerful
executive voice
it can be uncomfortable to recognize and
admit personal challenges regarding your
executive voice but by making the
necessary adjustments to your approach
to participation you can avoid flying
blind and start showing up more
strategically in every setting
[Music]
